00018 /**
00019 
00020 @page cn78xx_native CN7XXX native api reference
00021 
00022 Here CN7XXX means, CN78XX, CN73XX, CNF75XX that use OCTEON III packet IO blocks.
00023 
00024  - @ref cn78_pk_xmit
00025  - @ref cn78_pdesc
00026  - @ref cn78_bp
00027  - @ref cn78_fpa
00028  - @ref cn78_multinode
00029  - @ref cn78_pki
00030  - @ref cn78_new_apis
00031  - @ref cn78_multinode
00032 
00033 @section cn78_pk_xmit Packet transmission
00034 
00035 In the CN7XXX series, packet transmission is controlled by the structure 
00036 cvmx_pko3_pdesc_t. In contrast with the previous cvmx_pko_command_t structure, 
00037 the pdesc is a dynamic stack where additional operands can be pushed for 
00038 operation by the PKO. These commands can include pointers to packet 
00039 fragments, gather lists, crc specifications, memory write/modify operations, 
00040 and the traditional transmission complete work queue notifications.
00041 
00042 The following sections describe a new API that is designed to take full
00043 advantage of the CN7XXX PKO (a.k.a. PKO3) based on cvmx_pko3_pdesc_t.
00044 
00045 The memory space for the cvmx_pko3_pdesc_t structure is provided by the application.
00046 In most cases this space can be simply allocated as an automatic variable
00047 on the stack of the function that uses the following API.
00048 In some advanced use cases however, the pdesc_t object may be contained in
00049 an auxiliary data structure and persist across multiple iterations of
00050 the main packet processing loop.
00051 For example, an application that is designed to reassemble fragmented IP
00052 packets might declare a pdesc_t as one of the information element in its
00053 packet reassembly hash table, so that each pdesc_t represents an original
00054 IP packet while it is being reassembled.
00055 
00056 The pdesc_t may be initialized in one of two ways: (a) if the packet being
00057 processed has been received by the application via the SSO and PKI from one
00058 of the network interfaces, the native WQE structure may be converted to a
00059 pdesc_t by calling cvmx_pko3_pdesc_from_wqe().
00060 
00061 If, on contrast an application needs to *create* a packet to be transmitted,
00062 or build a packet from another source that is not represented by a WQE,
00063 it should first call cvmx_pko3_pdesc_init() that will create an *empty*
00064 packet descriptor that would be subsequently *filled" with buffers using
00065 the cvmx_pko3_pdesc_buf_append() function.
00066 
00067 In either case, the pdesc_t may be augmented with additional PKO-specific
00068 meta-data, such as a method the PKO should use to notify the application
00069 of a succesful packet transmission etc.
00070 
00071 Once the packet descriptor is *complete*, it can be transmitted to an
00072 egress port using the cvmx_pko3_pdesc_transmit() function.
00073 
00074 After cvmx_pko3_pdesc_transmit() returns, the pdesc_t structure
00075 can be re-used by the application to store a new packet (by calling
00076 cvmx_pko3_pdesc_from_wqe() or cvmx_pko3_pdesc_init() again).
00077 The buffers that are contained in a 'pdesc' should not be accessed by the
00078 application after calling cvmx_pko3_pdesc_transmit() in any way if the
00079 PKO has been instructed to *free* the packet buffers on completion.
00080 If the PKO has been programmed not to free the buffers, the 'pdesc' can
00081 be re-used by sending the exact same packet to a different destination port.
00082 The data in the buffers must not be modified after calling
00083 cvmx_pko3_pdesc_transmit() because the buffers may have not yet been
00084 consumed, and any modification could effect the prior packet.
00085 
00086 For example, never call cvmx_pko3_pdesc_hdr_push() or
00087 cvmx_pko3_pdesc_hdr_pop() on a pdesc_t following its transmission,
00088 but only after the pdesc_t has been re-initialized to be empty or from a WQE.
00089 
00090 @section cn78_pdesc Packet Descriptor Danipulation
00091 The 7XXX no longer has a hardware FAU unit, however the PKO now has an atomic 
00092 memory operation capability, allowing it to perform most of the same 
00093 functionality. In order to decrement a counter after transmission, add the 
00094 following call before cvmx_pko3_pdesc_transmit():
00095 
00096 cvmx_pko3_pdesc_notify_decrement(cvmx_pko3_pdesc_t *pdesc, volatile uint64_t *p_counter);
00097 
00098 WQE notification is handled via the cvmx_pko3_pdesc_notify_wqe() call, however 
00099 note the WQE format is in the 7XXX specific format. Unlike other commands, 
00100 only 1 WQE notification can be added per PKO operation.
00101 
00102 For a typical packet processing application, to make a packet received
00103 from an ingress port via the PKI, SSO in the form of a WQE,
00104 call cvmx_pko3_pdesc_from_wqe() to quickly convert the input packet
00105 to pdesc_t and make it ready for transmission.
00106 Following cvmx_pko3_pdesc_from_wqe() one may call cvmx_wqe_free()
00107 immediately, or at any later time, since all the data and meta-data
00108 for the packet has been saved in pdesc_t.
00109 
00110 If a received packet headers need to be modified, the prescribed method
00111 of modifying a packet header is made available with 'cvmx_pko3_pdesc_hdr_pop()'
00112 that will extract a packet header from the packet and save it in
00113 caller-provided buffer, and remove that header from the packet
00114 (hence extending its headroom).
00115 A new header can be prependend to the packet by calling
00116 cvmx_pko3_pdesc_hdr_push().
00117 
00118 For example, to forward a packet at Layer-2 between two different VLANs,
00119 the application would need to first remove the L2 header from the packet
00120 using cvmx_pko3_pdesc_hdr_pop(), modify its VLAN tag and any other Layer-2
00121 header fields, and the call cvmx_pko3_pdesc_hdr_push() to prepend a new
00122 Layer-2 header to the packet. Note that the new Layer-2 header may be
00123 of a different size than the original header, as would be in the case
00124 of a MAC-in-MAC tunneling application.
00125 
00126 For a simpler Layer-2 forwarding application that does not modify the
00127 headers, but needs to inspect the header contents for making a forwarding
00128 or learning operation, it may use cvmx_pko3_pdesc_hdr_peek() to get a copy
00129 of the Layer-2 header without modifying the packet contents.
00130 
00131 @section cn78_bp Backpressure
00132 
00133 The 78XX uses hardware counters called AURAs to control backpressure, RED and 
00134 drop thresholds. You may enable flow control on per-aura basis by calling 
00135 cvmx_fpa3_setup_aura_qos(), with the thresholds you wish to use. For example, 
00136 for an aura attached to a shared pool with 800 buffers you could specify cvmx_fpa3_setup_aura_qos(). Which would configure the specified aura to pass all packets when at least 200 
00137 buffers were free, send backpressure notification when 100 buffers are free, and 
00138 to drop all packets when only 50 buffers are free. The auras should be considered 
00139 on a per-style basis, in such a way that a single style consuming too many 
00140 resources will be throttled gracefully while all other traffic is continue. 
00141 
00142 @section cn78_fpa CN78XX-specific FPA3 API details
00143 
00144 One major difference between the 2 chip generations is the existence of auras. 
00145 For 78xx boards in legacy mode, any references to pools are expected to target 
00146 auras, and any devices which in the past would require pools for their memory 
00147 will now instead use an aura id in place. Pool 0 will be disabled, so that any 
00148 misconfigured aura accesses will fail on the simulator. There are new helper api
00149 calls to make pool/aura configuration easier:
00150 
00151 cvmx_fpa3_setup_aura_and_pool() will allocate and set up a single aura with a backing pool of given size. 
00152 The aura id is returned, and the api will attempt to reserve the specified aura id
00153 unless given -1, in which case aura ids will be allocated dynamically. If 
00154 buffers == NULL then memory will be allocated automatically.
00155 The backing pool number will be reserved dynamically, and the 'num_blocks'
00156 argument is used both for the actual number of buffers that populate the
00157 pool, and the allocation buffer limit that will be assigned to the aura.
00158 
00159 cvmx_fpa3_set_aura_for_pool() is used to attach auras to an existing pool, which can be created
00160 and filled with buffers using cvmx_fpa3_setup_fill_pool(),
00161 or by calling cvmx_fpa3_aura_to_pool()
00162 that will return the id of the pool that is baking the specified aura.
00163 The 'num_blocks" argument to cvmx_fpa3_set_aura_for_pool() is used
00164 to limit the number of buffers that can be consumed through the new aura,
00165 and should be less than or equal to the number of buffers contained in
00166 the backing pool it is associated with.
00167 The 'block_size" argument is only used to verify that the backing pool
00168 was created with the same buffer size that the application expects with
00169 this new aura, to avoid unpredictable behavior.
00170 
00171 An end user should rarely attempt to reserve a specific pool id on 78xx,
00172 as the handle given to all I/O blocks, and used to allocate buffers is an aura.
00173 
00174 Beyond initialization and shutdown the only occasion the pool id should be
00175 used is when attaching an additional aura to an already configured pool.
00176 
00177 One of the key changes in cn78xx is that the new Buffer Link Pointer no longer 
00178 includes the "Back" field, which is used on older chip to indicate the distance 
00179 from the start of data to the beginning of the buffer in cache lines.
00180 For this reason, the only method that can be relied on at all times for the FPA 
00181 to locate the beginning of a buffer to free, is to use the native alignment mode, 
00182 where the buffer start is always aligned to the buffer size for a given POOL.
00183 Other alignment modes of the FPA can only be expected to work if the 1ST_SKIP and NEXT_SKIP
00184 values in PKI (as well as the distance to start of data in any software-generated packet)
00185 are always less then cache line size. Taking advantage of this restriction is highly
00186 discouraged.
00187 
00188 @section cn78_pki CN78XX-specific packet input (PKI) details
00189 
00190 PKI can be broken down in 7 major areas, where backward compatibilty needs to be addressed
00191 
00192  - @ref pki_if_cfg
00193  - @ref wqe_and_pb_pools
00194  - @ref wqe_fields
00195  - @ref qos_and_queue_prio
00196  - @ref pkt_sched
00197  - @ref pki_red_and_bp
00198  - @ref pki_cfg
00199 
00200 @subsection pki_if_cfg Interface/Port Configuration
00201     Software in previous chips controls the per port (interface/index) configuration for packet input block through
00202         provisioning the pkind registers. In 78xx port configuration is controlled via style registers.
00203     pkind configuration registers only control few aspect of port. To configure the port, a style needs to be
00204     assigned to the port first and after that configuration can be controlled through that style register.
00205 
00206       To keep backward compatibility, SE library be default assigns style = pkind for that port.
00207       "cvmx_pip_config_port" supports the backward compatibility for many fields. Some fields that are not supported are qos
00208            and group watchers, portadd_en and different tagging mechanism for different protocols.
00209 
00210 
00211 @subsection wqe_and_pb_pools WQE and packet buffer pools
00212     In older chips pacwqe and packet data could reside in separate pools. Packet data buffers were hardwired to come from pool 0.
00213 
00214     78xx Support-- 78xx has concept of auras and any aura can be assigned to buffer the packet data.
00215 
00216       To keep backward compatibilty all the packet data from all interface/ports are still buffered in aura0.
00217       By default SDK supports NO_WPTR mode where wqe entry uses same buffer as packet data and is appended
00218            to first packet buffer.
00219     Older chips supported 2 mode for packet buffering.
00220 
00221     a) WQE and packet data reside in different buffers which comes from different fpa pools. wqe buffers contains wqe descriptor
00222            and 12 words of packet data.
00223            78xx support --- In 78xx this mode to keep wqe entry and packet data in different buffers can be chosen by calling api "cvmx_helper_pki_set_wqe_mode".
00224            Note that buffers for wqe still comes from the same packet pool. There is no need to configure WQE buffer pool.
00225            You may want to increase the size of packet pool since now wqe buffers comes from there. Take note that this
00226            may increase the memory footprint.
00227            Also WQE buffer only contains first few words 5-8 depending on wqe_header_size chosen in configuration.
00228            If application need first few words of packet data to be in WQE, they will need to copy them themselves.
00229            Also notice that WQE entry now has minimum of 5 words compare to 4 words before.
00230 
00231     b) WQE_NOPTR: WQE and packet data share the same buffer, where 4 WQE WORDS are appended in front of packet data.
00232 
00233        78xx support -- This is default mode in 78xx where wqe is appended in front of the first packet data buffer.
00234                78XX has minimum 5 words and there is a word after that for next_ptr field for linked buffers.
00235                next_ptr field is there even for packets which needs only 1 buffer.
00236 
00237 
00238 @subsection wqe_fields WQE fields
00239     WQE structure has been almost completely modified in 78xx. If software is accessing the fields of it directly,
00240         it needs to modify the code to use accessor functions.
00241     Unused fields are not supported.
00242 
00243 @subsection pkt_sched Packet Scheduling
00244     In older chips by default SE software sends packets to 8 different qos queues. There are no separate qos queues in 78xx,
00245         sso groups can be used as qos queues within.
00246 
00247         78xx support: In backward compatible mode by default all packets from all interfaces/ports go to sso group 0.
00248 
00249 @subsection qos_and_queue_prio QOS and QUEUE PRIORITIES
00250         In older chips sso could prioritize scheduling of work based on QOS queues0-7, in 78xx prioritization is based on groups.
00251         Each group can be prioritized between priorities 0-7. 78xx has 256 groups which are configured in software, so that lowest 3
00252         bits of group denotes priority and remaining 5 bits represent a group which limits group numbers to 32 in backward
00253         compatible mode.
00254         68xx had many ways to configure QoS which are outlined below
00255                 1) per port QoS queue and group --
00256                         It could be configured through PIP_PRT_CFGX register by calling API
00257                         cvmx_pip_config_port() which now have support for 78xx
00258                 2) QoS watchers --
00259                         software will reserve pcam entries 0-7 for qos watcher 0-7. In 78xx qos is controlled
00260                         via sso groups so there is no separate control for qos.
00261                 3) priority table --
00262                         user need to config qpg table where grp = grp << 3 | qos, padd, bpid per port/channel are not supported in
00263                         backward compatible mode. user need to setup qpg_base by calling cvmx_pki_write_style_cfg
00264                 4) bit selector --
00265                         can be achieved by programming pcam entries
00266 
00267 @subsection pki_red_and_bp PKI RED and backpressure
00268    RED is applied per aura, since in backward compatible mode all the packets goes to aura 0
00269    RED can't be applied on per port/interface basis.
00270    Back Pressure- There are no per port back pressure counters in 78xx, back pressure is applied per aura.
00271                    Since all the packets goes to same aura in backward compatible mode, backpressure can't be applied
00272                    on per interface/port.
00273 
00274 
00275 @section cn78_new_apis Using PKI New APIS for 78xx
00276 
00277 @subsection pki_cfg Steps to configure PKI
00278 1) On power on PKI is initialized to default parameters by software which assigns packet pool 0, sso group 0
00279    and 1:1 pkind:style mapping. It then enables PKI to send/receive traffic.
00280 
00281  To modify default parameters call
00282  
00283  - cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_pool(int node, int pool, int buffer_size, int buffer_count)
00284  
00285  - cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_aura(int node, int aura, int pool, int buffer_count)
00286 
00287  - cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_pool_buffer(int node, int buffer_count)
00288 
00289  - cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_aura_buffer(int node, int buffer_count)
00290 
00291  - cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_pkind_map(int node, int pkind, int style)
00292 
00293  - cvmx_helper_pki_get_dflt_style(int node, struct cvmx_pki_style_config *style_cfg)
00294 
00295  - cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_style(int node, struct cvmx_pki_style_config *style_cfg)
00296 
00297 To disable PKI default initialization call
00298 
00299  - cvmx_helper_pki_no_dflt_init(int node)
00300 
00301 2) Configure/Modify PKI global parameters(if needed) by calling
00302 
00303  - cvmx_pki_read_global_config(int node, struct cvmx_pki_global_config *gbl_cfg)
00304 
00305  - cvmx_pki_write_global_config(int node, struct cvmx_pki_global_config *gbl_cfg)
00306 
00307  - struct cvmx_pki_global_config contains all PKI global parameters which can be modified.
00308 
00309 3) Configure scheduling resources of interface/ports by calling api
00310         cvmx_helper_pki_init_interface(const int xiface, struct cvmx_pki_intf_schd *intfsch, struct cvmx_pki_global_schd *gblsch)
00311 
00312         OR
00313 
00314         cvmx_helper_pki_init_port(int ipd_port, struct cvmx_pki_prt_schd *prtsch)
00315 
00316 4) Modify port related parameter (if needed)) by calling
00317         cvmx_pki_get_port_config(int ipd_port, struct cvmx_pki_port_config *port_cfg)
00318 
00319         cvmx_pki_set_port_config(int ipd_port, struct cvmx_pki_port_config *port_cfg)
00320 
00321         If only flow profile related parameters need to be modified and many ports are sharing same profile,
00322         parameters can be modified by calling
00323                 cvmx_pki_read_style_config(int node, int style, uint64_t cluster_mask, struct cvmx_pki_style_config *style_cfg)
00324 
00325                 cvmx_pki_read_style_config(int node, int style, uint64_t cluster_mask,struct cvmx_pki_style_config *style_cfg)
00326 
00327 5) Install pcam entries (if needed) by calling
00328         cvmx_helper_pki_install_pcam_entry(int node, uint64_t cluster_mask, struct cvmx_pki_pcam_input input, struct cvmx_pki_pcam_action action)
00329 
00330 6) Enable RED and/or backpressure (if needed) using:
00331 
00332  cvmx_helper_pki_map_aura_chl_bpid(int node, uint16_t aura, uint16_t bpid,
00333                                       uint16_t chl_map[], uint16_t chl_cnt)
00334 
00335  cvmx_helper_setup_aura_qos(int node, int aura, bool ena_red, bool ena_drop, 
00336                                uint64_t pass_thresh, uint64_t drop_thresh, bool ena_bp, uint64_t bp_thresh)
00337         follow the code/example in passthrough-pktio.c
00338 
00339 7) Enable PKI to start processing packets by calling
00340         cvmx_helper_pki_enable(int node)
00341 
00342 @section cn78_multinode Multi-node data-types
00343  - SSO XGRP = (node << 8) | lgrp == (node << 8) | group << 3 | qos
00344  - PKO ipd_port = (node << 12) | chan_e
00345  - PKO: xqueue = (node << 10) | dq
00346  - XIFACE = node << 5 | local_iface
00347 
00348 Multinode mode on the cn78xx is implemented in 2 ways:
00349  - Compatibility mode where all calls are assumed to target current node hardware
00350     - Not all functionality is supported in compatibility mode, application instances are limited to a single node's cores, though communication can cross node boundaries via named-block memory.
00351  - Native mode where calls take a target node argument.
00352     - Limitations exist, while packets can be transmitted on any node's port by any core, packet reception and get_work is restricted to the local node (though add_work can be sent across node boundaries, work can only be received by a node's cores).
00353 
00354 Loading executables on multiple nodes:
00355 - bootoct has been modified to support multiple nodes on 78xx, the command takes additional arguments as follows:
00356     bootoct [addr] -nodemask=[nodemask to run on, ie 0x3 for nodes 0 and 1] -coremask=[coremask on node0],[coremask on node1]
00357 
00358 Execution on all nodes/cores will be suspended until node0/core0 has been booted, so coremask 0x1 must be specified last.
00359 
00360 */
